title: Sydney train delays: Wynyard signal failure, broken train at Central cause chaos
text:
How do Australia's train networks compare to one another?

Sydney’s rail system has been brought to its knees this morning after a broken down train at Central and a signal failure at Wynyard caused widespread chaos.

Central and Wynyard are two of the city’s busiest and best-connected stations meaning the delays and chaos spread to most of Sydney’s lines.

The broken-down train at Central was moved around 8.30am but not before it caused numerous flow-on delays.

Sydney Trains is working to calm customers down with one spokesperson telling a disgruntled commuter the system was “165 years old”.

The issue this morning was not related to a maintenance issue. This is a 165-year old network, experiencing unprecedented growth with 1.4 million customer journeys a day. — T1 Sydney Trains (@T1SydneyTrains) October 10, 2019

Commuters coming from the north and west were worst off with some Friday train travellers left sitting on Sydney Harbour Bridge for close to an hour.

“Not the best way to start a Friday. I stepped on the train at 7.10 and didn’t get to Central until after 8,” Vanessa, commuting from Kirribilli, told news.com.au.

“The driver tried to give us accurate updates on the signal problem at Wynyard...but a 10 minute delay blew out to 30 minutes so I think he was as clueless as everyone on board about what was going on.”

Another commuter claimed the train guard suggested they walk across the bridge to get to work in a timely fashion.

70 mins from Milsons point Wynyard. @sydneytrains advising to walk across the bridge. — Richard Spaven (@EUCNut) October 10, 2019

A woman also tweeted she had been told to jump between platforms for half an hour — to no avail.

@T4SydneyTrains what’s going on? I’ve been jumping from platform to platform for the past 30 minutes and still haven’t moved.. — abby (@abz________) October 10, 2019

When you’re conference started at 9am and your train terminates at central so you have to battle thousands of people just getting off the train let alone making further travel plans to walk 🏃‍♀️ #Sydneytrains #SydPos19 pic.twitter.com/wkdHSCLQlb — Mrs Rowl (@RowlUpToClass) October 10, 2019

Other angry commuters suggested they should’ve been given their morning trip for free or at a discounted rate.

“Every time there’s delays, Sydney trains should charge the fares at a discounted rate. Yeah they’ll lose profit but that should push them to make sure their services are efficient,” Paola Rondario said.

Sydney Transport Stats, which collates data from around the city, said more than a third of trips — 36 per cent — experienced delays this morning.

Sydney Trains’ Twitter accounts have been busy this morning and as of 9.30am were still advising commuters of flow-on delays.
description: Sydney’s rail system has been brought to its knees this morning after a broken down train at Central and a signal failure at Wynyard caused widespread chaos.
